SharedWorker.summary: The SharedWorker interface represents a specific kind of worker that can be accessed from several browsing contexts, such as multiple windows or iframes. Shared workers implement a different interface than dedicated workers, have a different global scope (), and their constructor is not exposed in , so they cannot be instantiated from dedicated workers.

blockquote.para: If SharedWorker can be accessed from several browsing contexts, all those browsing contexts must share the exact same origin (same protocol, host and port).

SharedWorkerError.summary: The error event of the interface fires when an error occurs in the worker.

SharedWorkerPort.summary:
The port property of the
interface returns a object used to communicate and control
the shared worker.

APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by having a Content Security Policy (CSP) that restricts the locations from which scripts can be loaded, and by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations in the Worker() constructor for more information.
The SharedWorker() constructor creates a object that executes the script at the specified URL.
